message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has purulent sputum and decreased levels of IgG and IgA, which are characteristic of Hyper-IgM syndrome. Otitis media and sinusitis are common infections in patients with this syndrome. Other options, such as Bruton agammaglobulinemia and Common variable immunodeficiency, may also cause recurrent infections, but they typically present with decreased levels of all immunoglobulins. Severe combined immunodeficiency typically presents with more severe infections and is usually diagnosed earlier in life.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has recurrent respiratory infections and low levels of IgG and IgA, which suggest a primary immunodeficiency disorder. Among the options given, only Hyper-IgM syndrome fits the description.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history and symptoms suggest a respiratory infection, and the gram-positive diplococci suggest Streptococcus pneumoniae, which is one of the common pathogens in Hyper-IgM syndrome. The decreased levels of IgG and IgA support the diagnosis. Bruton agammaglobulinemia and Common variable immunodeficiency usually have decreased levels of all immunoglobulins, while Severe combined immunodeficiency has severe impairment of both T and B cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has normal levels of IgM but decreased levels of IgG and IgA, which suggests a diagnosis of Hyper-IgM syndrome. The repeated episodes of otitis media and bacterial sinusitis also support this diagnosis. Gram-positive diplococci may be indicative of Streptococcus pneumoniae, a common pathogen in patients with Hyper-IgM syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of recurrent infections, decreased levels of IgG and IgA, and purulent sputum from both nares. These suggest hyper-IgM syndrome as the most likely underlying diagnosis. Otitis media and bacterial sinusitis are also common infections in this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of recurrent infections and decreased levels of IgG and IgA, which are characteristic of Hyper-IgM syndrome. The gram-positive diplococci in the sputum suggest a possible bacterial infection. Other options would present with more severe or frequent infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with recurrent infections and decreased levels of IgG and IgA, which are characteristics of Hyper-IgM syndrome. The other options are less likely, as Bruton agammaglobulinemia would show decreased levels of all immunoglobulins, Common variable immunodeficiency would present with low levels of all immunoglobulins and recurrent infections, and Severe combined immunodeficiency would present with persistent infections from early infancy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history and laboratory findings suggest hyper-IgM syndrome. This is supported by the normal IgM levels and decreased IgG and IgA levels. The recurrent infections also suggest an immunodeficiency disorder. Bruton agammaglobulinemia and common variable immunodeficiency present with recurrent bacterial infections and low levels of all immunoglobulin classes. Severe combined immunodeficiency presents with recurrent infections including viral and fungal infections, and would have been diagnosed earlier in life.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of recurrent infections, a productive cough and purulent sputum, and decreased levels of IgG and IgA, which suggest a primary immunodeficiency disorder. Among the options, the most likely diagnosis is Hyper-IgM syndrome, which is characterized by decreased levels of IgG and IgA and recurrent infections. Bruton agammaglobulinemia presents with very low levels of all immunoglobulins, Common variable immunodeficiency presents with low levels of multiple immunoglobulins, and Severe combined immunodeficiency presents with a complete lack of T cells and a dysfunctional immune system.

We refer to the Mayo Clinic's article on antibody deficiencies for help. The patient's decreased levels of IgG and IgA in the setting of recurrent infections suggest Hyper-IgM syndrome as the most likely underlying diagnosis. Other options, such as Bruton agammaglobulinemia and Common variable immunodeficiency, present with more significant recurrent infections and are usually diagnosed earlier in life. Severe combined immunodeficiency is also a possibility but is more severe and presents earlier in life.
